dead.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Her mother had been dead for ten years.
Police are trying to contact the family of the dead man.
the dead body of a young soldier
Two men were shot dead by terrorists.
Magnus was found dead in his car.
One man is still missing, presumed dead.
He suddenly had a heart attack and dropped dead.
She was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital.
His fellow climbers had left him for dead on the mountain.
We didn’t know if she was dead or alive.
When they found him he was more dead than alive.
dead.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: not working because there is no power
dead.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I picked up the phone but discovered the line was dead.
I think the batteries are dead.
dead glass/bottle (=one that someone has finished drinking from in a bar or restaurant)
dead.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: a small pile of dead matches
dead.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a place that is dead is boring because there is nothing interesting or exciting happening there
dead.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: This place is dead after nine o'clock.
dead.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The luxury car market has been dead in recent months.
dead.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a part of your body that is dead has no feeling in it, especially because the blood supply to it has been stopped
dead.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: When I got up my foot had gone dead where I’d been sitting on it.
dead.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Jennie’s eyes were cold and dead.
dead.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: I can’t go out tonight. I’m absolutely dead!
She was dead on her feet and didn’t have the energy to argue  (=used when someone keeps going even though they are very tired).
dead.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: completely or exactly – used to emphasize what you are saying
dead.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: We all sat waiting in dead silence (=complete silence).
The train came to a dead stop (=it stopped completely).
The arrow hit the dead centre of the target  (=the exact centre).
I’ve given the whole thing up as a dead loss (=completely useless or a complete failure).
John tells me it’s a dead cert, we can’t lose  (=something which will certainly happen, win, succeed etc).
He fell to the floor in a dead faint (=completely unconscious).
dead.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: You’re in dead trouble now  (=in very serious trouble)!
One word of this to Sam and you’re dead meat (=you are in serious trouble and someone is very angry with you)!
If Mum finds out about this, I’m dead.
dead.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: a dead planet has no life on it
dead.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: when the ball is dead in some games, it is no longer on the playing area
dead.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: lie dead
If I’m late, Mum worries that I’m lying dead somewhere.
drop dead
He dropped dead at the age of 52.
find somebody dead
A man was found dead in the apartment.
shoot somebody dead
He was jailed for life for shooting dead a burglar.
leave somebody dead
The shooting left at least 28 people dead.
leave somebody for dead
The men beat him and ran away, leaving him for dead.
pronounce somebody dead
She was pronounced dead at the scene of the accident.
be feared dead
Hundreds of people are feared dead in a ferry disaster.
be presumed dead
The two boys have not been seen since they fell into the river, and are now presumed dead.
clinically dead
A person is declared clinically dead when the brain stops working.
a dead body
A dead body has been found in the woods.
long dead
All those people I knew then are long dead now.
dead and gone
Let’s face it, we’ll all be dead and gone soon.
more dead than alive
He was swept up onto a beach after three days at sea, more dead than alive.
dead.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: the bodies of three dead soldiers
dead or seeming to be dead
dead – use this as a polite way of talking about someone who has died, especially recently
a gold Cartier bracelet that once belonged to the late American artist Andy Warhol
Her parents, now deceased, disapproved of her marriage.
They were friends of the deceased  (=the person who died).
dead – used in order to be polite and avoid saying the word ‘dead’
They paid their respects to their departed uncle.
dead – used especially when someone was alive not long before
dead.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: When he saw her, he stopped dead in his tracks (=suddenly stopped moving completely).
Her family were dead against the marriage.
dead.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: I stared dead ahead at the doorway.
The bus arrived dead on time.
dead.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: You’re dead wrong, so let me handle this.
The countryside around here is dead flat all the way to the sea.
The room was dead quiet while we waited for Ted to reply.
He came home dead drunk in the middle of the night.
I’d like to be an actress but Mum and Dad are dead set against it.
At the moment, Steve’s just dead set on winning the gold medal.
She was so shocked that she stopped dead in her tracks.
dead.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: if the economy or an industry is dead, it is not growing or successful
dead.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The plan is to lower interest rates in order to breathe life back into the dead economy.
The domestic gold industry is dead.
dead.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: no longer important, being used, or popular
dead.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Takeover investing isn’t dead, despite all the new state anti-takeover laws.
